related_questions.question: What is antibody treatment?
related_questions.title: AI Overview
list: Targeting Specific Antigens: Antibodies are proteins that have a specific shape that allows them to bind to a corresponding "keyhole" or antigen on a cell.

Mimicking the Immune System: Monoclonal antibodies are designed to act like natural antibodies, either by directly binding to and neutralizing a pathogen (like a virus) or by marking a cell for destruction by the immune system.
Direct Action or Immune Boost: Some monoclonal antibodies directly target and kill cancer cells, while others help the immune system recognize and destroy cancer cells more effectively.
Delivery of Treatment: In some cases, monoclonal antibodies are combined with other therapies, like chemotherapy (antibody-drug conjugates), to deliver the treatment directly to cancer cells.
Cancer: . Opens in new tabMonoclonal antibodies are used in various cancers, including breast cancer, lymphoma, and leukemia, to target specific proteins on cancer cells.
COVID-19: . Opens in new tabCertain monoclonal antibodies have been authorized for treating COVID-19, particularly in high-risk individuals.
Other diseases: . Opens in new tabMonoclonal antibodies are also used in treating autoimmune disorders, organ transplant rejection, and other conditions.
Naked monoclonal antibodies: These antibodies work by themselves to target specific cells.
Conjugated monoclonal antibodies: These antibodies are linked to other treatments like chemotherapy or radioactive particles.
Bispecific antibodies: These antibodies can bind to two different targets, potentially bringing immune cells closer to cancer cells.
Specificity: Monoclonal antibodies are highly specific, meaning they target a particular antigen on a particular cell type, which helps minimize damage to healthy cells.
Side Effects: While generally safer than some other treatments, monoclonal antibodies can still cause side effects, which can vary depending on the specific antibody and the condition being treated.
Efficacy: The effectiveness of monoclonal antibody treatment can vary depending on the individual, the disease, and other factors.
